title: FBI worker, 60, who died after 'falling into a creek' in North Carolina is investigated
text:
Officials are investigating the 'suspicious' death of an FBI worker who was found in a creek in North Carolina.

Kathleen Miller's body was found on October 7 in Nantahala National Forest after officials received a call from a caller to say a woman had fallen into a creek.

The 60-year-old was pronounced dead at the scene when authorities arrived a short time later and an investigation has now begun.

Kathleen Miller , (pictured), was found dead on October 7 in Nantahala National Forest after officials received a call from a caller to say a woman had fallen into a creek

Officials said they received a call stating that a woman had fallen into water at a creek in Nantahala National Forest and there was difficulty getting her out

District Attorney Ashley Welch told the Asheville Citizen Times that Miller was employed by the FBI as a forensic photographer in Huntsville, Alabama.

She told the Asheville Citizen Times that her office was investigating the death from a 'criminal standpoint.'

'Any time the D.A.'s office gets involved, I think it's safe to say we were looking into suspicious circumstances.'

Graham County Sheriff's office said they did not believe there was any threat to the public.

In a statement on Facebook, the office said: 'The Graham County Sheriff’s Office, State Bureau of Investigation, United States Forest Service and the District Attorney’s Office are involved in the investigation.

'This incident is being looked into from a criminal standpoint, but we want to reassure folks that there isn’t any danger to the public.

'More information will be released pursuant to the investigation process.'

The News & Observer reported that Miller's husband was with her at the time of her death and called 911.

Kathleen Miller was employed by the FBI as a forensic photographer in Huntsville, Alabama and was not on duty at the time of her death

Miller's friend Gail Jones said her friend was a kind and loving person. The two women are pictured together left

A spokesman for the Birmingham Field Office of the FBI confirmed that Miller was not on duty at the time of her death.

Miller's friend Gail Jones told WHNT that she was a 'kind, fun loving person.'

She added: 'Kathy was a beautiful person. She was fun-loving, very smart and very creative. 'She loved photography in high school and studied that in college,' she added.

She said Miller grew up in Geneva, New York and went to college in Rochester.

'She always saw the best in people and was very forgiving,' Jones added.

Her friends told WHNT that they believe Miller was expected to be back at work in Huntsville on the same day she was found dead

A sheriff's department lieutenant told the outlet that the incident happened off the road on Santeetlah Creek uphill from Stewart Cabin

Her friends told WHNT that they believe Miller was expected to be back at work in Huntsville on the same day she was found dead. It is understood she was not on duty at the time of her death.

On October 7, a 911 caller at 5.17pm reported that a woman had fallen in water and could not be gotten out.

The emergency call recording obtained by the Citizen Times claimed that a man making the call can be heard saying there was no cell service where it happened on Big Santeetlah Road.

He indicated that he was in contact with an individual in a pick-up truck who drove up the road from near some cabins where it happened.

A sheriff's department lieutenant told the outlet that the incident happened off the road on Santeetlah Creek uphill from Stewart Cabin.

Shanteetlah Creek is in western North Carolina, about 225 miles from Charlotte and is a popular fishing location.
description: Kathleen Miller was found dead near a creek in North Carolina on October 7. Cops say they are examining the death of the FBI worker at Nantahala National Forest from a 'criminal standpoint.'
